TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in LOC . Having been granted legal aid , the applicant is represented by PERSON , a lawyer practising in PERSON . The respondent Government are represented by PERSON , their Agent .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
The applicant was employed and , as such , contributed to the ORG pension scheme ( dôchodkové zabezpečenie ) .
On DATE he retired and started receiving a retirement pension .
In DATE the applicant restarted working as a night watchman . As he was simultaneously receiving a retirement pension , he acquired the status of an “ employed pensioner ” .

Being employed , he was liable to pay income tax on his salary . Being a pensioner , he was not entitled to have a so - called “ untaxable amount ” deducted from his income tax base unlike other employed persons .

On DATE an amendment ( Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL Coll . ) to ORG ( Law no . CARDINAL Coll . – “ the LAW ” ) entered into force . It cancelled an exemption , which employed pensioners had enjoyed until then , from the obligation to pay contributions to the State pension scheme . The applicant thus became liable to contribute to this fund like any other employed person .
On DATE another amendment ( Law no . CARDINAL Coll . ) to LAW entered into force which re - introduced the above exemption .
DATE and DATE the applicant paid CARDINAL NORP korunas ( SKK ) in contributions to the pension scheme .
The applicant unsuccessfully requested the President , ORG , ORG and ORG to bring about a change in the relevant legislation .

In a letter of CARDINAL October CARDINAL the Prosecutor General informed the applicant that employed pensioners were not eligible for the deduction of the untaxable amount from their income tax base unless the total of their pension was less than the untaxable amount . If their pension was below the untaxable amount , an amount equal to the difference between the actual pension and the untaxable amount would be deducted from the tax base on their salary .

The letter further explained that the purpose of the pension scheme was to provide income for persons who were unable to provide for themselves by working , for example on account of their retirement age . As the ORG allowed retired persons to obtain income from employment in addition to their retirement pension , it was justified to impose certain restrictions on them , for example by taxing their salaries .
As for the applicant ’s complaint that he was liable to contribute to the pension fund , he was informed that as from DATE the rules had changed ( see above ) .
On DATE the applicant brought an action against the ORG in the form of ORG in LOC ( ORG súd ) . He sought repayment of the contributions which he had paid to the pension scheme DATE ( see above ) .
On DATE the Banská Bystrica District Court forwarded the action to the Bratislava I ORG on the ground that it fell within the territorial jurisdiction of the latter court .

On DATE the Bratislava I ORG submitted the question of jurisdiction to ORG ( Najvyšší súd ) , which ruled on DATE that the action should be determined at first instance by GPE . However , the case file was only forwarded to that court on DATE .
On DATE ORG requested the defendant to submit observations in reply , which ORG did on DATE .
ORG scheduled a hearing for DATE . The applicant stated that he would not be able to appear . He submitted his arguments in writing and requested the court to hear the case in his absence .

On DATE ORG held a hearing following which , on DATE , it dismissed the action . Having heard the defendant ’s representative and having examined complex documentary evidence , the court found that the amount claimed had been withheld from the applicant ’s salary under the relevant provisions of LAW . ORG had not breached any legal obligation and thus could not be held responsible for any loss incurred by the applicant .

The judgment of DATE was served on the applicant on DATE . On DATE he appealed arguing that the bill for the amendment no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL Coll . had been drafted by ORG and that , therefore , it was the ORG which was liable for the damage caused to him by implementing that amendment .
On DATE ORG requested the defendant to submit observations in reply to the appeal , which ORG did on DATE .

ORG ( Krajský súd ) listed a hearing of the appeal for CARDINAL DATE . The applicant stated that he would not be able to appear . He requested the court to hear the case in his absence and submitted his arguments in writing .

On DATE ORG upheld the first - instance judgment . It observed that before a bill became law it was subject to a complex legislative process . Drafting and submitting a bill as such could not engage liability for damage . There was no indication that the ORG had breached any legal duty in connection with the process of amending LAW .
The appellate court ’s judgment was served on the applicant on DATE .

On DATE the applicant lodged a complaint under LAW with ORG ( Ústavný súd ) . He directed the complaint against the GPE I ORG and argued , in substance , that the length of the proceedings had been excessive . He claimed SKK CARDINAL by way of just satisfaction .
On DATE , on his request , ORG appointed an ex officio lawyer to the applicant and , at the same time , declared the complaint admissible .
In DATE the applicant requested his lawyer for a report on the progress of the proceedings .

In a letter of DATE the lawyer informed the applicant that at ORG request he had provided further and better particulars of the complaint and had agreed to ORG deciding on the case without holding an oral hearing .

In a letter of CARDINAL DATE the applicant informed the lawyer that , by accepting that there would be no public hearing before ORG , the lawyer had acted contrary to the applicant ’s right to be heard in court .
On DATE the applicant made a written submission to ORG in which he sought to include in his constitutional complaint the undue delays in the proceedings before ORG .

On DATE ORG found that the GPE ORG had violated the applicant ’s right to a hearing “ without unjustified delay ” ( LAW ) and “ within a reasonable time ” ( LAW ) . It awarded the applicant LAW by way of just satisfaction in respect of his nonpecuniary damage and ordered the reimbursement of his legal costs .
ORG found that the overall length of the proceedings had been DATE and DATE . During that period , the case had been pending before ORG for DATE and before ORG for DATE .

However , the subject - matter of the constitutional proceedings had been determined by the admissibility decision of DATE which , as the applicant ’s original complaint , concerned the proceedings before ORG alone . Therefore , in the framework of the present constitutional proceedings , it was not possible to examine the proceedings before ORG which the applicant had contested after the admissibility decision .
As regards the proceedings before the Bratislava I ORG , ORG found that an unjustified delay had occurred DATE and DATE ( i.e. DATE ) .

All human beings are equal in dignity and rights ( LAW ) regardless of sex , race , colour , language , faith , religion , political affiliation or conviction , national or social origin , nationality or ethnic origin , property , birth or any other status ( LAW ) .
Every person has the right to have his or her case tried without unjustified delay ( LAW ) .
Income from employment is subject to personal income tax ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ( a ) in conjunction with section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) .
The personal income tax base is in general calculated as the difference between the income and the expense incurred in order to achieve it ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) .
The tax base does not comprise income exempted from tax ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) such as , for example , a retirement pension ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) .

Section CARDINAL defines untaxable amounts which are to be deducted from the tax base . These include inter alia SKK DATE in respect of the taxpayer himself ( subsection CARDINAL ( a ) ) . This amount can not be deducted if the taxpayer was receiving a retirement pension at the beginning of the taxation period unless the total of the pension is less than the above untaxable amount . In the latter case the taxpayer can deduct the difference between the untaxable amount and the pension received ( subsection CARDINAL ) .
Employed persons ( zamestnanci ) and their employers are liable to pay contributions to the pension scheme ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ( a ) and ( d ) ) .
Employed persons , who were receiving a retirement pension , were exempted from such liability ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ( e ) ) until DATE .
As from DATE the exemption under LAW ( CARDINAL ) ( e ) was repealed by amendment no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL Coll . and then reintroduced by amendment no . PERSON . as from DATE .

The amendment no . CARDINAL Coll . had been drafted by an individual member of the parliament . In the explanatory report ( dôvodová správa ) on the bill the deputy considered that the repeal of the exemption under LAW ( CARDINAL ) ( e ) had been contra ORG mores in that employed pensioners had been made to contribute to the pension scheme but had received nothing in return .

ORG submitted the bill to the ORG with an introductory report ( predkladacia správa ) in which they disagreed with the drafter . According to this report the exemption in question had given an unjustified advantage to employed pensioners over other employed persons in that as no contributions had been associated with the employment of pensioners , the latter group had been a more attractive work force than other employees . This had distorted the labour market and had to be corrected by the amendment no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL Coll . Another reason for that amendment had been the recent passive balance of the retirement pension fund .

The situation of persons who are employed after becoming entitled to a retirement pension but do not draw such a pension is addressed in LAW . The amount of the pension to which they are entitled increases with the length of their employment after retirement age according to a formula defined in sub - section CARDINAL .

If a person entitled to a retirement pension takes up employment , the retirement pension is suspended ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) , unless the employment is for a term shorter than DATE ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) .

On DATE another amendment ( Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL Coll . ) to FAC entered into force . It again repealed the exemption under LAW ( CARDINAL ) ( e ) and provided that employed persons participate in the pension scheme and are liable to pay contributions to the pension fund ( subsection CARDINAL ) .
As from DATE the SSA Act lost legal effect and the social security regulation was completely re - codified .

Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides that national laws may provide that the benefit of a person otherwise entitled to it may be suspended if such a person is engaged in any prescribed gainful activity or that the benefit , if contributory , may be reduced where the earnings of the beneficiary exceed a prescribed amount and , if non - contributory , may be reduced where the earnings of the beneficiary or his other means or the CARDINAL taken together exceed a prescribed amount .
